title: 114_hr3869
content: The Act titled "State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015" mandates coordination between state and local entities on cybersecurity with the National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new subsection focusing on State and Local Coordination on Cybersecurity. This involves assisting State and local governments in identifying information system vulnerabilities and security protections in line with cybersecurity risks. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to assist State and local governments in identifying information system vulnerabilities and security protections related to cybersecurity risks. Additionally, the act mandates working with senior State and local government officials to coordinate a nationwide effort for effective implementation of cybersecurity measures. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to coordinate a nationwide effort with State and local officials to ensure effective implementation of information security tools and provide cybersecurity training to government analysts and operators. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to provide cybersecurity training and assistance to State and local government analysts and operators upon request. This includes operational, technical, privacy, and civil liberties training in coordination with relevant officers of the Department. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to provide cybersecurity training and assistance to State and local governments. This includes operational and technical assistance to implement tools, products, resources, policies, guidelines, and procedures on information security. This assistance involves deploying technology for continuous diagnosis and mitigation against cyber threats and vulnerabilities, as well as compiling and analyzing data. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to provide cybersecurity training and assistance to State and local governments, including continuous diagnosis and mitigation against cyber threats, compiling and analyzing data on information security, and conducting targeted operational evaluations. Privacy and civil liberties training for Federal civilian information systems must align with the Department's Fair Information Practice Principles. The Fair Information Practice Principles under the Privacy Act of 1974 aim to limit the use and disclosure of cybersecurity information not essential for protecting information systems from risks. The curr_chunk discusses the need to protect information systems from cybersecurity risks and incidents while minimizing impact on privacy and civil liberties. It emphasizes the importance of data integrity by promptly removing irrelevant personal information. The curr_chunk emphasizes the need to safeguard cyber threat indicators and defensive measures, including proprietary or business-sensitive information, to prevent unauthorized access or acquisition. The curr_chunk highlights the importance of protecting confidential cyber threat indicators and defensive measures, ensuring privacy and legal protections are upheld. The national cybersecurity and communications integration center of the Department of Homeland Security must report on the activities and effectiveness of cybersecurity measures to congressional committees within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The national cybersecurity and communications integration center must report to congressional committees on the effectiveness of cybersecurity activities, including feedback from State and local governments. The House of Representatives passed the information required under this subsection on December 10, 2015. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
